items.title: Getting "error: package android.view does not exist" error while migrating my existing Android Project from Java 8 to Java 11
items.body:
I am wotking on multi-module Android project, currently this project is using Java 8 and as part of requirement I am upgrading this project to Java 11. Below is what I tried so far to achive the same-

1] Installed JDK-11 and set JDK location pointing to java-11 (i.e. File --> Project Structure --> SDK Location --> JDK Location)

2] As it is multi-module project, I did below chages in all module-level build.gradle files-

android{
       ...
    compileOptions {
        sourceCompatibility JavaVersion.VERSION_11
        targetCompatibility JavaVersion.VERSION_11
    }

    kotlinOptions {
        jvmTarget = '11'
    } 
}

Then I am able to Sync and Build the project successfully, but when I'm trying to run the project, I'm getting "error: package android.view does not exist" error and some other related errors, please check below screenshot for more details--

I goolged this error and found couple of related posts on Stackoverflow (below are the links) but haven't found any concrete solution yet.

1] error: package android.view does not exist

2] Migrating Java 8 project to Java 11

3] android + sourceCompatibility JavaVersion.VERSION_11: error: package android.os does not exist

  • Important: I am using Android-Studio Version 4.1.2 and MacBook with macOS Big Sur

Also, please let me know in-case any other details required. Thank you!

comments.body_markdown: You are doing very random stuff in your loop. Why is there a `zos.finish();` in there? Why do you write the file data to `os`, not `zos`? The order in the loop needs to be `putNextEntry`, `write`, `closeEntry`, all performed on the `ZipOutputStream`.
comments.body: You are doing very random stuff in your loop. Why is there a zos.finish(); in there? Why do you write the file data to os, not zos? The order in the loop needs to be putNextEntry, write, closeEntry, all performed on the ZipOutputStream.

answers.title: How do i add files into a zip for download?
answers.body:
The flow in the loop is:

  1. putNextEntry,
  2. write (to zos, not os!)
  3. closeEntry.

After the loop you need to call either close or finish on zos. If not, the ZIP file won't be properly ended. Since its underlying stream is not yours (the container owns it), I'd use finish:

ZipOutputStream zos = new ZipOutputStream(os);
System.out.println("================== Starting zip ==================");
for(FileUpload fu : fileToDownload) {
    System.out.println("Zipping " + fu.getFile_name() + ".....");
    ZipEntry zipEntry = new ZipEntry(fu.getFile_name());

    zos.putNextEntry(zipEntry);
    zos.write(fu.getFile_data());
    zos.closeEntry();
}
zos.finish();

System.out.println("================== Finish zipping. ==================");

// Don't close zos or os; flushing shouldn't be necessary but won't hurt

                    FileUpload fu = new FileUpload();
                    fu.setFile_id(selectedFiles[i]);
                    fileToDownload.add(fu);
                    System.out.println("fileToDownload file_id is " + fileToDownload.get(i).getFile_id());
                }
                // store details of downloads into fileToDownload
                fileToDownload = fuMapper.downloadMultipleAsZip(fileToDownload);
                
                //Do download
                OutputStream os = null;
                
                try {                  
                    response.setContentType("application/zip");
                    response.setHeader("Content-Disposition", "attachment; filename=download.zip");
                    
                    os = response.getOutputStream();
                    
                    ZipOutputStream zos = new ZipOutputStream(os);
                    System.out.println("================== Starting zip ==================");
                    for(FileUpload fu : fileToDownload) {
                        System.out.println("Zipping " + fu.getFile_name() + ".....");
                        ZipEntry zipEntry = new ZipEntry(fu.getFile_name());
                        
                        os.write(fu.getFile_data());
                        zos.finish();
                        zos.putNextEntry(zipEntry);
                        zos.closeEntry();
                        
                        } 
                    System.out.println("================== Finish zipping. ==================");
                    
                    os.flush();
                    zos.close();
                    os.close();
                    } catch (Exception e) {
                        e.printStackTrace();
                    }
                        
        }

comments.body_markdown: Also `return String(Base64.getEncoder().encode(byteEncryptedData), charset("UTF-8"))` as ASCII will not work on platforms with default UTF-16 or EBCDIC.

comments.body_markdown: No, for encode Base64, which delivers ASCII bytes, you still need for conversion to String specify an encoding, as the default could not be a superset of ASCII. `new String(byte[], Charset)` to explicitly define the charset of the bytes. However you can skip the step in java with `Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString`

items.body_markdown:
I am using this code.

    fun rsaEncrypt(rsaPublicKey: String, aesKey: ByteArray?): String {
        var result: String? = null
        val keyFactory = KeyFactory.getInstance("RSA")
        val keyBytes = Base64.getDecoder().decode(rsaPublicKey.toByteArray(charset("UTF-8")))
        val spec = X509EncodedKeySpec(keyBytes)
        val fileGeneratedPublicKey = keyFactory.generatePublic(spec)
        val key = fileGeneratedPublicKey as RSAPublicKey
        val cipher = Cipher.getInstance("RSA")
        cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, key)
        val byteEncryptedData = cipher.doFinal(aesKey)
        return String(Base64.getEncoder().encode(byteEncryptedData))
    }

But it only works over Oreo(Android OS veresion, API 26). But I need to make it work under API 26. At most API 24. Is there any alternative way to implement it?
items.title: What is the replacement for Base64.getEncoder().encode() in Kotlin?
items.body:
I am using this code.

fun rsaEncrypt(rsaPublicKey: String, aesKey: ByteArray?): String {
    var result: String? = null
    val keyFactory = KeyFactory.getInstance("RSA")
    val keyBytes = Base64.getDecoder().decode(rsaPublicKey.toByteArray(charset("UTF-8")))
    val spec = X509EncodedKeySpec(keyBytes)
    val fileGeneratedPublicKey = keyFactory.generatePublic(spec)
    val key = fileGeneratedPublicKey as RSAPublicKey
    val cipher = Cipher.getInstance("RSA")
    cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, key)
    val byteEncryptedData = cipher.doFinal(aesKey)
    return String(Base64.getEncoder().encode(byteEncryptedData))
}

But it only works over Oreo(Android OS veresion, API 26). But I need to make it work under API 26. At most API 24. Is there any alternative way to implement it?

My SearchSectionPmo class looks as follows:


```
package org.linkki_framework.tutorial.application_tutorial1;

import java.util.function.Consumer;

import org.linkki.core.ui.element.annotation.UIButton;
import org.linkki.core.ui.element.annotation.UITextField;
import org.linkki.core.ui.layout.annotation.UISection;

@UISection
public class SearchSectionPmo {
    private String searchText = "";
    private Consumer<String> searchConsumer;
    
    
    public SearchSectionPmo(Consumer<String> searchConsumer) {
        this.searchConsumer = searchConsumer;
    }

    @UITextField(position = 10, label = "")
    public String getSearchText() {
        return searchText;
    }

    public void setSearchText(String searchText) {
        this.searchText = searchText;
    }
    
    
    @UIButton(position = 20, caption = "Start Search")
    public void search() {
        searchConsumer.accept(getSearchText());
    }
}
```
I don´t really know what is wrong with the searchText. <br /> Is another problem causing this? I hope someone can help me.
<br />
I use Java 11 and Vaadin 23.1.3.
items.title: Created a linkki project following the tutorial. Got a BeanCreationException

answers.title: How to parse multiple types using jackson @JsonSerialize annotation?
answers.body:
You can both serialize and deserialize an enum by adding the @JsonValue annotation (see this answer). The following example is based on your enum:

public class Main {

    public static enum StatusEnum {
        ON(1),
        OFF(0);

        private final Integer code;

        StatusEnum(Integer code) {
            this.code = code;
        }

        @JsonValue
        public Integer getCode() {
            return code;
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) throws JsonProcessingException {
        ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();

        String jsonString = objectMapper.writeValueAsString(StatusEnum.ON);
        System.out.println(jsonString);

        StatusEnum readEnum = objectMapper.readValue(jsonString, StatusEnum.class);
        System.out.println(readEnum);
    }
}

The program outputs:

1
ON

items.title: How to parse multiple types using jackson @JsonSerialize annotation?
items.body:
I use @JsonSerialize to convert the enum class to Integer, and the writing is successful; but each enum class must write a converted class, is there a way to write only one conversion class?

I tried to use generics to get the type of the enum class, but failed, this is not allowed

//   error code

@JsonSerialize(using = StatusSerializer<StatusEnum>.class)
private Integer status;

@Data
public class ZkUser   {


    /**
     * name
     */
    private String name;

    /**
     * status
     */
    @JsonSerialize(using = StatusSerializer.class)
    private Integer status;


}

//==========================================================================================
public enum StatusEnum {

   // d
    ON(1),
   
    OFF(0);

    private final Integer code;


    public static StatusEnum getEnumByCode(Integer code) {
        for (StatusEnum s : values()) {
            if (s.code.equals(code)) {
                return s;
            }

        }
        return null;
    }

    StatusEnum(Integer code) {
        this.code = code;
    }
    
    public Integer getCode() {
        return code;
    }
}

//=========================================================================================
public class StatusSerializer<T> extends JsonSerializer<Integer> {

    private T t;


    @Override
    public void serialize(Integer value, JsonGenerator jsonGenerator, SerializerProvider serializerProvider) throws IOException {

            var b = StatusEnum.getEnumByCode(value);
            jsonGenerator.writeObject(b);
    }


}

answers.body_markdown:
Velocity 2.x uses the slf4j logging API. It means that you have to put in the classpath one of the available slf4j implementations :

- [slf4j-simple](https://www.slf4j.org/api/org/slf4j/simple/SimpleLogger.html ) that will log by default to `System.err`, you can configure the output file with the `org.slf4j.simpleLogger.logFile` system property
- [logback](https://logback.qos.ch/), a full fledged logger similar to log4j configurable with a `logback.xml` and which will allow advanced features like log files rotation
- [webapp-slf4j-logger](https://github.com/arkanovicz/webapp-slf4j-logger) that will redirect log towards the J2EE container logger in the context of a J2EE webapp
- several others around...

Libraries using slf4j cannot be aware themselves of what happens to logged messages, this decoupling has proven to be quite an improvement and has contributed to the success of the slf4j logging library.
answers.title: How to set the path for the velocity log file?
answers.body:
Velocity 2.x uses the slf4j logging API. It means that you have to put in the classpath one of the available slf4j implementations :

  • slf4j-simple that will log by default to System.err, you can configure the output file with the org.slf4j.simpleLogger.logFile system property
  • logback, a full fledged logger similar to log4j configurable with a logback.xml and which will allow advanced features like log files rotation
  • webapp-slf4j-logger that will redirect log towards the J2EE container logger in the context of a J2EE webapp
  • several others around...

Libraries using slf4j cannot be aware themselves of what happens to logged messages, this decoupling has proven to be quite an improvement and has contributed to the success of the slf4j logging library.
